newsitem.title: UK: BUSINESSMAN IN UK SOCCER BRIBE CASE PLEADS INNOCENCE.
newsitem.headline: BUSINESSMAN IN UK SOCCER BRIBE CASE PLEADS INNOCENCE.

text.p: The Malaysian businessman at the centre of a sensational soccer match-fixing trial has made a heartfelt plea of innocence, saying he never paid players to throw top-level matches.

"I have been waiting for two years to come here and explain my situation. This is the situation. I have not waited all this while to come here and tell some sort of fantasy," Heng Suan Lim told the courtroom in an impassioned outburst on Wednesday.
Lim denies he paid former Liverpool goalkeeper Bruce Grobbelaar and one-time Wimbledon keeper Hans Segers to throw matches on behalf of a Far Eastern betting syndicate.
Instead, he admits he paid the two men for help in forecasting the results of Dutch and English league matches. passing on the information to a wealthy Indonesian gambler.
"Imagine if I suggested to Grobbelaar that he fix matches...probably I would be flying from the window of his penthouse," Lim said. Segers, he added, "would have fainted and not got up again".
Lim and former striker John Fashanu are accused of paying Grobbelaar and Segers to throw matches. All four deny the charges, which carry a maximum seven-year sentence.
Fashanu was expected to be cross-examined at some stage on Thursday. The case, the first of its kind in England for more than 30 years, has attracted intense media interest.
Prosecutor David Calvert Smith suggested it was too much of a coincidence that Lim had been paying goalkeepers, the players most likely to be able to affect the result of a match.

"I would say it is purely coincidence. If I was knowledgeable in Dutch football as well as English football, Mr Segers would not be forecasting for me," said Lim, adding he had paid the Dutchman around 40,000 pounds ($65,000).
Lim said on Tuesday he had paid Grobbelaar a fraction of that amount, whereas the prosecution allege he paid the keeper 40,000 pounds for rigging a single game in late 1993.
The prosecution says Lim, 31, received around 500,000 pounds ($800,000) from various Asian sources which he then used to pay the other members of the alleged match-fixing ring.

Calvert Smith said Lim's only apparent regular source of income was regular contributions from Josef, a wealthy cocoa commodity trader. Lim said his benefactor rewarded him with huge sums of money when his bets paid off.

"Win or lose, he will not moan or show any dissatisfaction -- he bets as a hobby," said Lim, who admitted on Tuesday to losing 175,000 pounds ($280,000) in casinos. Josef stopped paying him when he learned about the losses, he said.
